overview.summary: A command-line Scrabble helper program built with Deno and TypeScript. The project computes Scrabble word scores and determines the highest-value word from a list, with a focus on clean CLI interaction and simple algorithm design.
overview.problem: Manually calculating Scrabble scores for multiple words can be time-consuming and error-prone, especially when validating words against a dictionary.
overview.solution: A lightweight CLI tool that accepts command-line arguments, validates words against a predefined list, and accurately computes total and highest Scrabble scores.

responsibilities: Designed and implemented a command-line application using Deno and TypeScript
Implemented Scrabble letter scoring logic using constants
Validated words against a predefined dictionary
Implemented logic for total score and highest-value word calculation

architecture.approach: Single-entry CLI application with logic decomposed into small, focused functions, emphasizing readability, maintainability, and academic best practices.
architecture.data_flow: Command-line arguments are parsed at runtime; words are validated against a predefined list; scores are calculated using letter-value mappings and returned via standard output.
architecture.deployment: Not deployed. The application is intended to be run locally using Deno.

challenges_and_learnings: Designing clear and predictable CLI program flow
Structuring TypeScript code without unnecessary complexity
Separating scoring logic from input handling
Handling edge cases such as invalid words and empty input
future_improvements: Add support for bonus tiles (double letter, triple word, etc.)
Improve error messaging for invalid usage
Add automated tests for scoring functions
Support reading words from a file
